sen.j: 西園寺 公顕（さいおんじ きんあき、文永11年（1274年） - 元応3年2月8日 (旧暦)（1321年3月7日））は、鎌倉時代後期の公卿。
sen.e: Kinaki SAIONJI (西園寺 公顕, 1274 - March 15, 1321) was a Kugyo (high court noble) in the Late Kamakura period.
sen.cmt: 「元応3年2月8日」は、【換暦】によるとグレゴリオ暦で「1321年3月15日」、ユリウス暦で「1321年3月7日」になるそうです。
sen.e: Kinaki SAIONJI (西園寺 公顕, 1274 - March 15, 1321) was a Kugyo (high court noble) in the late Kamakura period.
sen.cmt: Lateの頭文字が大文字でしたが、小文字に直しました。
sen.e: Kinaki SAIONJI (西園寺 公顕, 1274 - March 15, 1321) was a Kugyo (high court noble) in the late Kamakura period.

sen.j: 主に伏見天皇（92代）から花園天皇（95代）までの四帝にわたり仕え、官位は従一位右大臣まで昇る。
sen.e: He worked mainly for the four emperors from Emperor Fushimi (the 92nd generation) to Emperor Hanazono (the 95th generation), and rose up to Juichii Udaijin (Junior First Rank, Minister of the right) in official court ranks.

sen.j: 母は内大臣花山院師継の娘。

sen.j: 兄に左大臣西園寺公衡、弟に太政大臣今出川兼秀がいる。
sen.e: He had an older brother named Kinhira SAIONJI who was Sadaijin (Minister of the Left), and a younger brother named Kanehide IMADEGAWA who was Daijo-daijin.

sen.j: 娘西園寺婉子は関白二条道平の正室。
sen.e: He had a daughter named Enshi SAIONJI who was the legal wife of Kanpaku (Chief Adviser to the Emperor) Michihira NIJO.

sen.j: 以降累進して、正応3年（1290年）参議となり、公卿に列する。
sen.e: After that, he was promoted successively, and in 1290, he was appointed as Sangi (Councilor) to rank with Kugyo.

sen.e: In 1307, he was appointed as Togu Gon no Daibu (Provisional Master of the Crown Prince's Quarters) for Crown Prince Tomihito Shinno (Imperial Prince, and later Emperor Hanazono), but the next year, he resigned his position because the prince was enthroned.

sen.j: 京極派の歌人として新後撰和歌集以下の勅撰和歌集に計24首採録されているが、政治的才能には乏しかったとされ、『花園天皇宸記』文保元年3月26・27日条には公顕が県召除目の大間書執筆を担当した際に、その作法が分らずに娘婿の二条道平が天皇の御前で舅に教えている有様に記主である花園天皇が憤慨したことが記されている。
sen.e: While, as a kajin (waka poet) of the Kyogoku school of poetry, he had 24 poems of his own adopted in Chokusen wakashu (anthologies of Japanese poetry compiled by Imperial command) subsequent to Shingosen Wakashu (New Later Collection of Japanese poems), it is said that he was poor in abilities as a politician, and it is recorded in the articles of March 26 and 27 of the first year of Bunpo era (in the old lunar calendar, that is, May 15 and 16 of 1317 in the Gregorian calendar) of "Hanazono Tenno Shinki" (The Records of Emperor Hanazono) that when Kinaki was in charge of writing Omagaki (a list of candidates) of Agatameshi no jimoku (ceremony for appointing local officials), because he didn't know the manner, he learned it from the husband of his daughter Michihira NIJO in the presence of Emperor Hanazono, and that the emperor who wrote these records was indignant at their behaviors.
